subject: Re: [junit] written recommendation of super.setUp/tearDown ?
msgSnippet: ... Tests won t be subclasses of anything, so I don t know whether it ll matter. But still, I don t know why it s a design smell to have to invoke super.xxx()
messageBody:
Allan Halme wrote:
> Do we know whether JUnit 4 will be resolving this "design smell", i.e. will
> it no longer require subclasses of TestCase to explicitly remember to call
> super.setUp and super.tearDown() ?

Tests won't be subclasses of anything, so I don't know whether it'll matter.

But still, I don't know why it's a design smell to have to invoke
super.xxx() when you override and want to decorate a method's behavior.
That's just OO. As I wrote elsewhere, if super.xxx() bothers you,
refactor to Template Method.

> One other thing that has to be remembered, that I always initially forget,
> is that--at least in my test fixtures--you'll want to call super.setUp()
> _first_ in your subclass's overriding method, but you'll want to call
> super.tearDown() correspondingly _last_ in its overriding method ...

Not always, but usually. I have needed to call super.setUp() and
tearDown() near the middle of tests that require setting up heavily
foreign-key-laden data in a database.

Remember that they're almost always the reverse, I get. :)
--
